item.title: About Me
item.description: My name is Eric Joraskie, and I am a computer science graduate student at Northeastern University. I’ve had an unusual path into CS. After majoring in neuroscience at Northwestern University (and loving it), I worked in a few roles that left me longing for more intellectual stimulation. After much introspection and experientation, it became clear that computer science could offer me a route to solving complex problems I found interesting and cared about.

item.title: Athletics
item.description: Although I enjoying being althletic and I was a full scholarship athlete, please don’t ask me any questions about sports because I don’t follow any and won’t know the answers. I do care about physical and mental health though and worked as a personal trainer (ACSM-CPT, although I let it lapse) and cycling instructor (Schwinn Indoor Cycling Cert) for NU Recreation after I medically retired from football. I currently serve as the defacto personal trainer for all of my close friends.

item.title: Photography
item.description: I’ve been fascinated with photography since I was a kid.* Luckily for me, my high school had a TV Studio extracurricular that gave me the opportunity to spend a lot of time using DSLRs, shoulder-mount video cameras and a few different professional photo and video editing softwares, so I was able to get a reasonable amount of practice fairly early on. Now I mainly use a DJI Mavic Air 2, a Sony Cybershot that is a few years old but still great, and I have a Rylo (r.

item.title: Projects
item.description: I’ve written a lot of code and enjoy writing code, so that volume is growing. That being said, I’m relatively selective about what I keep in a public repository. Here are a couple of projects that I’ve worked on with links to what is available. I will update this page as I make more code available on github. Othello Optical Escape

item.title: Reading List
item.description: I read a lot. It’s usually nonfiction but I’ve included some of my favorite novels too. Here is a quick list of eight of my favorites I’d be willing to risk my recommendation reputation on. I’ve linked them all to their page on Goodreads and the authors are linked to the best info source I could quickly find. I’m actually not really a fan of Goodreads (mainly their webpage design; I think their pages are very cluttered), but I figured it was better than linking directly to Amazon, although I understand it’s only really one additional step.
